author: Yago González
title: El comercio minorista de Asturias hará huelga el 23, 24, 30 y 31 de diciembre
text:
El comercio minorista de Asturias anuncia huelgas para el 23, 24, 30 y 31 de diciembre
El sector, con más de 11.000 trabajadores, reclama mejoras en el nuevo convenio colectivo, mientras la patronal llama a la "tranquilidad" y confía en que se logre un acuerdo
Los trabajadores del comercio minorista en Asturias, incluidos los supermercados, harán huelga en los días clave de Navidad: 23, 24, 30 y 31 de diciembre. Así lo han acordado los sindicatos UGT, CC OO, USO y FETICO en la asamblea celebrada este domingo el Lugones. El motivo que aducen los representantes sindicales de un sector con más de 11.000 profesionales en la región es la discrepancia con la patronal en torno al convenio colectivo en negociación.
Los sindicatos afirmaron el pasado viernes que las negociaciones están paralizadas por el "abismo" existente entre las condiciones que propone la patronal y las reivindicaciones de los trabajadores. Por ejemplo, en materia salarial, estos piden un incremento del 4% para este año, frente a la propuesta de la patronal del 2,8% para 2024 el y 2,5% en 2025.
Según las organizaciones sindicales, en cuatro de los niveles profesionales recogidos por el convenio el salario coincide con el salario mínimo interprofesional y "casi no hay diferencia" entre categorías con diferencias responsabilidades. También lamentan que "no se hayan producido avances" tras varias reuniones en los últimos meses.
Por su parte, la Asociación de Supermercados de Asturias (Asupa) ha lanzado, tras el anuncio de la huelga, "un mensaje de tranquilidad a empleados y clientes", y se ha mostrado "convencida" de que "negociando de buena fe y pensando en el beneficio de los trabajadores no habrá huelga y finalmente se alcanzará un acuerdo".

author: @CSIMarket
title: Regis Corporation Faces Delisting Threat: Appeals NYSE's Decision and Explores New Listing Opportunities to Protect Common Stock Value
text: Regis Corporation Faces Delisting Threat: Appeals NYSE's Decision and Explores New Listing Opportunities to Protect Common Stock Value Published / Modified Dec 28 2023 CSIMarket Team / CSIMarket.com Regis Corporation Appeals NYSE Decision and Explores Listing Options: The Future of its Common Stock Hangs in the Balancea prominent player in the haircare industry, recently announced its decision to appeal the New York Stock Exchange's (NYSE) determination to commence proceedings to delist Regis' common stock. In response to this development, the company has requested an oral hearing during which it plans to present its compliance plan to the NYSE. In the meantime, Regis remains committed to evaluating all available listing options. Regis Corporation, Regis Corporation, The NYSE's decision to initiate the delisting proceedings has undoubtedly created uncertainties for Regis Corporation. However, the company's adamant appeal reflects its determination to tackle this challenge head-on. By opting for an oral hearing, Regis aims to leverage the opportunity to present its comprehensive plan of compliance, ensuring a fair evaluation of its efforts to meet the NYSE's requirements. Despite the ongoing appeal process, it is important to note that the trading of Regis common stock has not been suspended.Consequently, investors can still actively trade Regis shares, albeit under the shadow of potential delisting. This situation places existing and potential shareholders in a precarious position, as the outcome of the appeal will significantly impact the stock's future prospects. Regis Corporation's dedication to exploring all available listing options illustrates its commitment to maintaining a strong market presence. By actively evaluating various alternatives, such as alternative stock exchanges or over-the-counter (OTC) trading platforms, the company demonstrates its desire to provide reliable and accessible avenues through which investors can engage with its stocks. The appeal and subsequent hearings will likely prove critical for Regis Corporation's long-term prospects in the haircare industry. As the company seeks to impress upon the NYSE its commitment to compliance, it must also consider the potential consequences of delisting. Should Regis' common stock be delisted, the company's ability to attract institutional investors, access capital markets, and maintain investor confidence could be significantly impacted. Furthermore, the relisting process, should the appeal prove unsuccessful, can entail significant costs and administrative burdens. Regis Corporation would need to navigate through extensive regulatory requirements and potentially reestablish its credibility to potential investors. While these challenges are not insurmountable, they certainly represent hurdles that Regis must face should they fail to successfully overturn the NYSE's decision. Overall, the future of Regis Corporation's common stock remains uncertain as the company appeals the NYSE's decision to commence delisting proceedings. With the appeal providing a platform for Regis to present its plan of compliance, investors closely follow this pivotal development. Moreover, Regis' exploration of alternative listing options highlights its determination to ensure accessibility to investors despite potential delisting. As the haircare industry eagerly awaits the outcome of this appeal,it remains to be seen whether Regis can successfully navigate these challenges and secure a prosperous future for its common stock. author: Juliana De Los Ríos
title: Fondo de Agua Bogotá-Región presenta proyectos de restauración hídrica con comunidades
text:
Cundinamarca
Bogotá continúa con la medida del racionamiento de agua debido a la crisis hídrica en la que están los embalses que le surten este servicio a la ciudad.
Bajo este contexto, entidades tanto públicas como privadas le han apostado a proyectos que buscan proteger el agua y articular alianzas entre actores. Un ejemplo de estas es el Fondo de Agua Bogotá-Región.
Con más de 10 años de trabajo, el Fondo ha logrado proteger más de 8.000 hectáreas de ecosistemas estratégicos e involucrar a más de 5.000 familias en estas actividades de conservación.
Proyectos como ‘Entornos Sostenibles’, apoyado por l a Corporación Autónoma Regional de Cundinamarca , son la muestra de que el sector privado, el público y la comunidad pueden apostarle al mismo objetivo: fortalecer los acueductos veredales.
“ Estamos muy enganchados en seguir fortaleciendo acueductos veredales no solamente desde la inversión de la infraestructura, sino en las capacidades de las personas. Creo que si tenemos mejor capacitación en terreno, en términos contables, en términos de administración de recursos, las comunidades van a ser mucho más resilientes para poder tener mecanismos de sostenibilidad", indicó la directora, Andrea Yáñez.
Así como ‘Entornos Sostenibles’ hay al menos 5 proyectos más dirigidos por el Fondo que impulsan la participación de las comunidades.
Yáñez resaltó la importancia de medir los resultados de los proyectos para conocer su impacto.
“ En términos de medición volumétrica es importante para poder fortalecer esas juntas de acción comunal. Ahí tenemos unos resultados bien interesantes en términos de la capacidad de sostenibilidad de estos procesos”, aseguró la directora.
Este 2025, el Fondo le apuesta a trascender fronteras físicas y llegar más allá de la región de la cuenca del río Bogotá.
“El sueño también es fuertemente trabajar con la región central porque no solamente la situación se presenta en Bogotá, el Meta es muy importante, Tolima, Huila, Boyacá por supuesto y Cundinamarca “, resaltó la directora explicando que la seguridad hídrica.

author: Lakisha Davis
title: The Evolution of Digital Marketing in 2025
text:
How to win in digital marketing in 2025? As we approach this pivotal year, digital marketing is on the brink of significant transformation. With rapid technological advancements and changing consumer behaviors, marketers must adapt to maintain their competitive edge. Leaders like Micky Weis are offering insights into the future of marketing strategies.
The landscape of digital marketing is constantly evolving, driven by technological innovations and shifts in consumer behavior. As we look toward 2025, understanding emerging trends will be crucial for marketing in the UAE with marketers aiming to engage effectively with their audiences. Staying informed about these changes is essential for anyone involved in digital marketing.
Trends in Digital Marketing Artificial intelligence is set to revolutionize ecommerce and customer interactions by providing personalized marketing experiences. AI’s ability to analyze large datasets enables marketers to tailor experiences that align with consumer preferences. Additionally, optimizing for voice search is becoming increasingly important as more users rely on voice assistants for online searches. Keeping pace with these technological trends is vital for maintaining a competitive advantage.
Personalized marketing goes beyond customization; it involves creating meaningful connections with consumers. By leveraging data-driven insights, businesses can craft messages that resonate with individual needs, fostering loyalty and engagement. Strategies in digital marketing now focus on using these insights to create seamless experiences across various platforms. As technology advances, so will the methods used to capture consumer attention.
The rise of augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) is reshaping how brands interact with consumers. These immersive technologies enable companies to create interactive product demonstrations, virtual try-ons and engaging branding experiences that blur the line between the digital and physical worlds. As hardware becomes more accessible and 5G networks expand, AR and VR applications are expected to become mainstream marketing tools by 2025, offering unprecedented opportunities for customer engagement and product visualization.
Strategies for Success To succeed in 2025, marketers must prioritize content marketing as a core component of their strategies. Creating engaging content that educates and entertains is crucial for capturing consumer interest in a crowded market. Social media engagement is also key, allowing brands to interact directly with their audience and build communities around shared interests. Working with digital marketing in Dubai requires an understanding of these principles to navigate diverse markets effectively.
Data-driven decision-making is a cornerstone of successful digital marketing campaigns. By analyzing consumer behavior patterns, businesses can make informed decisions about resource allocation for maximum impact. Insights from data analysis enhance targeting precision and enable real-time adjustments that improve campaign performance. In this evolving landscape, adaptability is essential.
Case Studies and Expert Opinions Real-world examples demonstrate the effectiveness of innovative digital marketing campaigns, showcasing how businesses have utilized cutting-edge technologies to achieve remarkable results. Industry leaders highlight the importance of staying ahead of trends and learning from both successes and failures. Micky Weis is recognized as a thought leader in this field, providing valuable perspectives on navigating the challenges and opportunities of the digital landscape.
Insights from experienced marketers reveal common themes across successful campaigns: creativity, innovation, and a deep understanding of consumer needs. These elements are crucial for developing strategies that exceed expectations. As the industry progresses toward 2025, embracing change is imperative for those looking to excel in digital marketing.
Preparing for the Future To prepare for the future of digital marketing, marketers must adopt a mindset focused on continuous learning and adaptation. Staying informed about emerging technologies and industry trends provides a significant advantage over competitors resistant to change. Emphasizing collaboration across departments can lead to more cohesive and effective strategies that drive business growth.
Encouraging experimentation as part of a forward-thinking strategy allows marketers to test new ideas and approaches without fear of failure. This approach fosters innovation and helps identify what resonates most with target audiences. By remaining open to new possibilities, marketers can position themselves at the forefront of industry advancements.

author: Rosa Soto
title: En Ecuador disponen nueva orden de prisión preventiva contra exjefe de la Judicatura
text:
EL NUEVO DIARIO, QUITO. – Un tribunal de Ecuador emitió este jueves una nueva orden de prisión preventiva por supuesta «obstrucción de la justicia» contra un exjefe del Consejo de la Judicatura, Wilman Terán, quien se encuentra en prisión por otro caso que indaga la presunta infiltración del narcotráfico en el sistema judicial.
La Fiscalía General del Estado informó que el juez Luis Rivera emitió órdenes de prisión preventiva, con fines de investigación, contra Terán y otros dos vocales del Consejo de la Judicatura, Javier M. y Maribel B., acusados por el Ministerio Público como «autores directos» del supuesto delito.
Indicaron que también han sido procesados como «cómplices» otros funcionarios del Consejo de la Judicatura identificados como Andrés J., Marcela V., Carlos G. y Katherine L., agregó la fuente.
Al concluir la audiencia, el juez Rivera acogió el pedido de la Fiscalía, dictó prisión preventiva contra Terán y Xavier M., mientras que a los otros cinco procesados les prohibió salir del país, presentarse periódicamente ante el tribunal y usar un grillete electrónico.
El magistrado también ordenó la retención de los valores y cuentas bancarias de los imputados, y les prohibió enajenar los bienes que estuvieran a su nombre.
Paralelamente, el juez Rivera emitió medidas de protección a favor del juez Walter Macías, el fiscal general subrogante, Wilson Toainga, y la agente fiscal Alexandra Zurita, por considerar que el Consejo de la Judicatura pudiera ejercer acciones de persecución e intimidación contra ellos por este caso.
Toainga, en la audiencia, relató que esta investigación fiscal comenzó en 2022 ante un supuesto delito de tráfico de influencias que salpicaba a exvocales del Consejo de la Judicatura como Juan José M. y Maribel B.
El caso recayó en el juez Macías, quien fue recusado por Maribel B., aunque la acción de la exvocal fue rechazada el 11 de mayo de 2023, horas antes de que la Judicatura suspendiera al juez Macías, en una sesión de esa entidad que, según la Fiscalía, estuvo marcada por irregularidades.
Para el Ministerio Público, aunque las entidades del Estado tienen atribuciones propias, éstas no pueden ser usadas de forma ilegítima en función de impedir la acción de los jueces.
La Fiscalía añadió que el delito de obstrucción de la justicia está tipificado y sancionado en un artículo del Código Orgánico Integral Penal.
El pasado 19 de diciembre, Terán, que había sido detenido pocos días antes tras una investigación fiscal relacionado con la supuesta infiltración del crimen organizado en el sistema judicial, presentaba desde la cárcel su carta de dimisión como presidente del Consejo de la Judicatura.
Ese mismo día, el Consejo de Administración Legislativa de la Asamblea Nacional (Parlamento) resolvía admitir a trámite una solicitud de juicio político contra Terán, así como contra los exvocales de la Judicatura Xavier Muñoz y Maribel Barrero, acusados por un presunto incumplimiento de funciones.
Terán fue detenido en el marco del denominado caso «Metástasis», sobre una presunta trama de corrupción en los sistemas judicial, carcelario y policial por infiltración y sobornos del narcotráfico.

author: Carmen Aguado
title: Palencia: El sol acompaña a los niños de Primera Comunión en la procesión del Corpus | El Norte de Castilla
text: PalenciaEl sol acompaña a los niños de Primera Comunión en la procesión del Corpus Secciones Servicios Destacamos PalenciaEl sol acompaña a los niños de Primera Comunión en la procesión del Corpus Palencia Necesitas ser suscriptor para acceder a esta funcionalidad. Domingo, 2 de junio 2024, 18:55 Necesitas ser suscriptor para acceder a esta funcionalidad. Compartir Los trajes y vestidos de comunión, con sus lazos y sus diademas de flores, las fotografías y los nervios previos volvían a protagonizar un año más la mañana de este domingo del Corpus Christi con la plaza de la Inmaculada y la Catedral de Palencia como eje principal ante los actos organizados para celebrar este día. Desde las diez y media de la mañana comenzaban a congregarse los primeros niños acompañados de sus padres que, emocionados, eran recibidos en el templo catedralicio, para asistir a la eucaristía a cargo del obispo de Palencia, Mikel Garciandía. En esta primera cita para el nuevo prelado, Garciandía recordaba ante los niños, sus catequistas, los padres y orgullosos abuelos el compromiso que conlleva y expresa salir en procesión por las calles de la ciudad después de haber recibido a Cristo en la Primera Comunión. Noticia relacionada «Hoy es un día especialmente luminoso para nosotros los cristianos católicos», destacaba en la homilía de una ceremonia que se extendió durante una hora y media mientras fuera se ultimaban todos los preparativos para la posterior procesión que daría comienzo tras la bendición final. Mientras, en las inmediaciones de la Catedral de Palencia se agolpaban familiares, amigos y también muchos palentinos que no querían perderse un año más este día tan especial en el que todos los niños que han recibido durante este año la Primera Comunión se reúnen para procesionar por las principales calles del centro. Un año más, la Cofradía del Santo Sepulcro de la capital ha sido la encargada de organizar todos los actos de la mañana de este domingo en la que los gigantes y cabezudos, la cruz y ciriales han vuelto a abrir la procesión. En ella, han participado doscientos poqueños pertenecientes a todas las parroquias palentinas donde durante el mes de mayo han recibido por primera vez este sacramento y lo han celebrado por todo lo alto con la familia y, desde hace unos pocos años, también con los amigos. A la salida después de la eucaristía, cuya organización ha recaído este año sobre la Parroquia de Nuestra Señora del Carmen, los gigantes y cabezudos abrían el séquito al que le ha seguido la banda de música y las primeros representantes de las cofradías. El viento también se ha querido colar en la celebración con alguna racha repentina que ha puesto en jaque los estandartes de las cofradías y también algún que otro vestido vaporoso. En cualquier caso, los niños, un año más, portaban en diferentes cestas de mimbre los pétalos con los que adornar su paso por el recorrido fijado. Tras ellos, la custodia del Corpus Christi que ha sido recibida por el grupo Danzas de Castilla y que ha procesionado delante de los represnetantes eclesiásticos y políticos de la capital. Los altares instalados por las cofradías se han sucedido por las principales calles por donde ha pasado el séquito, atrayendo la atención de los transeúntes y de sus cámaras. Los flashes se han sucedido durante todo el recorrido que ha partido de la plaza de la Inmaculada para después dirigirse a la iglesia de la Compañía tras recorrer Gil de Fuentes y llegar hasta los Cuatro Cantones, donde se ha podido ver a más gente esperando a ver a los niños de comunión. La vuelta a la tercera catedral más grande de España se retomó desde Barrio y Mier para volver a una repleta explanada frente al templo, donde ha concluido un año más esta cita que se ha desarrollado sin la amenaza de lluvia, a diferencia de otros años, lo que también ha hecho que se alargara algo más de lo previsto su duración. author: A.J. Wuest
title: Lauderdale Co. Navy veteran honored with atomic service medal
text: OAKLAND, Ala. ( WAFF ) - A U.S. Navy veteran from Lauderdale County knows what it’s like to feel the shock of an atomic bomb. “Like ants all over you. It felt like I was on fire,” Jimmy Wallace said, according to WAFF’s news partners at the TimesDaily . “When they dropped that thing you could see the bone of your arm.” And as a young sailor aboard the USS Curtiss AV-4 in the 1950s, it was all part of the job. During his four years in the Navy, Wallace said he experienced at least 10-12 nuclear blasts, according to the TimesDaily. Part of his duty was to explore radioactive islands, just days after atomic blasts, as part of military nuclear testing in the Marshall Islands. Last week, Wallace was awarded the Atomic Veterans Commemorative Service Medal by the U.S. Department of Defense at the American Legion Post 11 in Florence. A newly created award, Wallace’s daughter Shonda Hernandez filled out paperwork for her father to receive it. “It tickled me,” Wallace said. “I was glad to get it. It’s been a long time coming.” According to the TimesDaily, Wallace said he would now love to start a movement to have a highway in the Shoals area named Nuclear Veterans Highway. Click Here to Subscribe on YouTube: Watch the latest WAFF 48 news, sports & weather videos on our YouTube channel! Copyright 2024 WAFF. All rights reserved.

author: DailyNews Editor
title: Private 5G Network Deployment with Republic of Korea Navy | Computer…
text:
The Republic of Korea (ROK) Navy has taken a significant step in enhancing its national naval security force by selecting Samsung Electronics and KT Corporation to deploy a private 5G network for its Smart Naval Port project. This marks the first deployment of its kind at a Korean Naval base and aims to improve battleship and base operation support capabilities while achieving comprehensive base defence.
Samsung emphasized the importance of private 5G solutions for national defence sectors, highlighting the need for ultrafast speeds and hyper-connected communications to ensure foolproof and effective operation management. By building a highly reliable network dedicated to the navy, the deployment aims to increase security and reduce vulnerabilities.
The Korean consumer electronics giant and domestic telco will work together to build an intelligent and fully independent network infrastructure for the Republic of Korea Navy 2nd Fleet. The project, which began in the summer, is expected to be completed by December 2025. Samsung will provide its end-to-end private 5G network solution, including the private network 5G SA Compact Core, indoor and outdoor radio solutions, and network management software. These solutions will support the mid-band spectrum widely adopted for military usage.
In addition to providing enhanced connectivity and coverage, the deployment will focus on applying artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled connectivity solutions to support a variety of next-generation applications. These applications include a digital twin of the smart naval base, intelligent security monitoring, and a battleship operation management system. The digital twin will serve as a three-dimensional digital replica of the base, aiding in decision-making related to base resilience, efficiency, adaptability, and autonomy.
The intelligent security monitoring system will enhance base defence through real-time video control of operational forces, surveillance cameras for ammunition depots and armouries, and surveillance drones. This monitoring system will provide a holistic view of the base for optimal operational response in emergency situations. The battleship operation management system will integrate critical systems to streamline administrative work for navy personnel.
Samsung Electronics vice-president, Simon Lee, expressed excitement about deploying Korea’s first private 5G network at a naval base. He highlighted the security, reliability, and commercial expertise of Samsung’s private 5G solutions, which have been trusted by various private and public sectors in countries like South Korea, the US, and Japan. The collaboration with KT Corporation underscores Samsung’s commitment to unlocking the potential of 5G to meet the diverse needs of its customers.

author: Ansa
title: Rio Grande do Sul deve ter fortes chuvas hoje
text: Temporais podem agravar crise no estado, que já soma 107 mortos BRASÍLIA, 10 MAG - Novos temporais devem atingir nesta sexta-feira (10) o estado do Rio Grande do Sul (RS), cuja capital, Porto Alegre, pode registrar até 330 milímetros de chuvas até segunda-feira (13), de acordo com um alerta divulgado pelo Instituto Nacional de Meteorologia (Inmet). O órgão, em conjunto com o Centro Nacional de Monitoramento e Alertas de Desastres Naturais (Cemaden) e o Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (Inpe), emitiu uma "nota técnica sobre os riscos geo-hidrológicos" para o Rio Grande do Sul. "Entre sexta e segunda-feira, as chuvas serão mais intensas no centro-leste e nordeste do estado, incluindo a região metropolitana da capital, o que pode agravar ainda mais a situação", diz o comunicado. Até o momento, a Defesa Civil gaúcha confirmou 107 mortes na tragédia climática, enquanto 134 pessoas seguem desaparecidas, quase 400 mil estão fora de casa e 1,7 milhão foram afetadas. Além do temor por novas chuvas, cresce a insegurança em alguns bairros de Porto Alegre, onde foi reforçado o patrulhamento da Brigada Militar, com apoio da Força Nacional de Segurança Pública (FNSP) e da Polícia Federal (PF). .

author: Catherine Strohfeldt
title: Brisbane news LIVE update: Man accused of orchestrating partner's hit-and-run murder denied bail
text: Add articles to your saved list and come back to them any time. 1 of 2 A man accused of murdering his ex-partner by having her run over by an SUV to “break her legs” has been denied bail, with a judge citing the risk of witness tampering. Prosecutors allege 23-year-old Kiesha Thompson was deliberately struck by a Toyota LandCruiser Prado while walking home on a footpath from a childcare centre in Daisy Hill, in Brisbane’s south, on July 19, 2024. Thompson died in hospital that night. Police allege Kiesha Thompson, 23, was deliberately run down on the side of the road after she dropped her daughter at daycare. Tyler Scott William James, 27, of Acacia Ridge applied for bail in Queensland Supreme Court on Wednesday. He was charged with murder as a domestic violence offence when first arrested and later charged with attempting to pervert justice. James is accused of conspiring to have 24-year-old Larissa Rita Mae-Leigh Sant fit the SUV with false number plates and then drive the vehicle at Thompson. Here’s the full report . An Arizona man accused of communicating with an Australian family who carried out the deadly shooting at Wiemabilla, in Queensland, will face a delayed US trial due to his lawyer’s computer network being hacked. Brothers Nathaniel and Gareth Train used high-powered rifles during an ambush to kill Constables Matthew Arnold and Rachel McCrow at the remote property in December 2022. Arizona man Donald Day Jr, 60, was charged a year later in the US with making threats to public figures and FBI agents, and possessing illegal firearms. US District Judge John Tuchi has now ordered the trial start date be pushed back from April 22 to September 15. Tuchi had ruled in March that Queensland Police officers would be able to testify at the trial, after US prosecutors said their evidence was necessary to prove Day was serious when he made threats after the Wieambilla shootings. Day’s lawyer Jon Sands then applied to Judge Tuchi for a pre-trial conference and the trial itself to be delayed. Sands said the Federal Public Defender’s Office in Arizona had discovered ransomware affecting local file storage and data backup systems on its network. “At this time, the office has no access to its network and, accordingly, staff are limited in the work they can do.” Day entered pleas of not guilty to all charges in the Arizona District Court in May 2024 and has denied any involvement in the Wieambilla shootings. The maelstrom swirling around Donald Trump’s on-again-off-again tariff regime couldn’t feel more removed from the tranquil Cairns region that the prime minister is visiting today, as he campaigns to win the seat back from the opposition. But the spectre of another political leader looms nearly as large as the US head honcho, with Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek nowhere to be seen in Far North Queensland. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese on a boat to Green Island from Cairns, Queensland, in the electorate of Leichhardt on Thursday. Credit: Alex Ellinghausen Anthony Albanese this morning is preparing to board a boat and visit the Great Barrier Reef, the environmental asset many voters most closely associate with her role – given Plibersek lists its protection as a key justification for multi-million dollar federal funding – not to mention Labor’s ambitious climate change agenda. Missing today’s trip freezes Plibersek out of an announcement for the $6 million funding for Kids for the Reef rebates to subsidise school excursions to the Great Barrier Reef. Relations have been fraught for Albanese and Plibersek for a long time, given both are potential leadership rivals. But the relationship became particularly frosty in November, after the PM’s last-minute intervention to scupper Plibersek’s deal with the Greens for a key environmental reform. Not even a trip to Plibersek’s favourite tropical idyll could melt the tension. The Trump tariff turnaround is having an immediate impact on expectations about the Reserve Bank and interest rate settings. On Wednesday, markets had expected the RBA – which next meets in mid-May – to go on a rate-cutting splurge. RBA Governor Michelle Bullock. Credit: Alex Ellinghausen Five rate cuts by Christmas were expected, with a near-80 per cent chance the bank would start with a super-sized 0.5 percentage point cut next month. But with Trump in retreat, so are interest rate expectations. The chance of a 0.5 percentage point cut next month is down to 40 per cent while markets now reckon the bank will eventually deliver four rate cuts by Christmas. That’s still a long way from where markets and investors were just a fortnight ago, before Trump’s Liberation Day, when they believed the Reserve only had two rate cuts on the agenda by year’s end. Anthony Albanese is touring Far North Queensland today, as he campaigns to win back the seat of Leichardt based around Cairns. He’s announcing $10 million in funding for the region, including for tourism operators and $6 million to subsidise school excursions to the Great Barrier Reef. He will travel by boat to Green Island, near Cairns, to announce the funding. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese. Credit: Alex Ellinghausen Speaking to Cairns radio station 4CA, the PM touched on local infrastructure and tourism, before issuing his first response to Trump’s latest tariff move. The PM said it’s “a very uncertain world that we live in”. “That is why I’m absolutely certain now it’s not a time for chaos. Now it’s not a time for inexperienced people coming into government. Now it’s time for us to have a steady hand on the ship.” He added that he believed holding firm was the best course of action in response to the trade war. A Coalition senator has rejected China’s suggestion Australia should join hands with the global superpower in the face of Donald Trump’s trade war. Nationals Senator Matt Canavan told Nine’s Today that everyone was “having a meltdown” over Trump’s tariffs, despite the fact that Australia only exports 5 per cent of its products to the US, while suggesting Australia has “self-imposed” tariffs because of economic red tape and taxes. “Get rid of those things. That’s what we should do and free up our own country.” Nationals Senator Matt Canavan. Credit: Rhett Wyman The senator continued that it was clear Trump’s tariffs were “largely about trying to rein in the behaviour of China”. “That leaves us a little bit exposed because we are very exposed economically to China. And instead of diversifying our economy, the Anthony Albanese government has doubled down on that.” Asked for his take on China’s bid to “join hands” with Australia in response to the trade war, Canavan said it is clear that Australia should be “reducing our exposure to China”. He said he couldn’t see how the two countries could work together in the trade war given that in 2020 China issued demands that Australia refused, leading to tariffs on various Australian products. “What we’ve got to do is look after ourselves and look after our own country. What have so many resources in this nation that we should be investing in our own country.” Police are searching for a man last seen more than one week ago. Joe-Dylan Coombes went missing from Maryborough, about 250 kilometres north of Brisbane, on the night of March 29. Joe-Dylan Coombes. Credit: Queensland Police He was reportedly seen about 9.30pm walking west along Alice Street towards the Bruce Highway, and again about 30 minutes later on the Henry Palmer Bridge. The 26-year-old has short brown hair and green eyes. Police and the SES searched from the water and in helicopters near the bridge on Wednesday. Police are appealing to anyone with dashcam or CCTV vision of the area from that night to come forward. An 11-year-old boy has suffered life-threatening burns from a backyard fire at an east Brisbane property. Emergency services were called at 10.46pm last night, and arrived at the Britannia Avenue home to find the primary-school-aged boy had suffered burns to his face, head, arms and chest. He was transported to Queensland Children’s Hospital in a “serious but stable” condition last night. Police were investigating the circumstances leading to the fire. A man accused of murdering his ex-partner by having her run over by an SUV to “break her legs” has been denied bail, with a judge citing the risk of witness tampering. Prosecutors allege 23-year-old Kiesha Thompson was deliberately struck by a Toyota LandCruiser Prado while walking home on a footpath from a childcare centre in Daisy Hill, in Brisbane’s south, on July 19, 2024. Thompson died in hospital that night. Police allege Kiesha Thompson, 23, was deliberately run down on the side of the road after she dropped her daughter at daycare. Tyler Scott William James, 27, of Acacia Ridge applied for bail in Queensland Supreme Court on Wednesday. He was charged with murder as a domestic violence offence when first arrested and later charged with attempting to pervert justice. James is accused of conspiring to have 24-year-old Larissa Rita Mae-Leigh Sant fit the SUV with false number plates and then drive the vehicle at Thompson. Here’s the full report . A damp first week of school holidays warned of earlier in the week has not come to pass, and with luck Brisbane will stay relatively dry into the weekend. A shower is possible today in the River City, with a top of 27 degrees forecast for a cloudy day. So far, the weekend is looking touch and go, with a chance of a storm. The outlook is below, but we shall see tomorrow if the bureau’s forecast changes. Here’s what’s making news further afield this morning: Wealthy donors sensing a Labor win are tipping big money into Anthony Albanese’s campaign to give him a financial edge over Peter Dutton , who will hit up Melbourne blue-bloods on Thursday night to fund a late campaign advertising splurge. President Donald Trump has “paused” his so-called reciprocal tariffs for the next 90 days while increasing the levy on Chinese imports to an unprecedented 125 per cent in a stunning about-face that sent sharemarkets skyrocketing China is offering to work with Australia to boost trade and defend growth in response to tariffs imposed by Trump in a new bid to find common ground when the world is spiralling into a catastrophic trade war. An online game which encourages players to sexually assault their in-game mother and “make all women yours” was available on a popular gaming platform accessed by Australian children and has since been removed. And, asks City Reporter Courtney Kruk, politics is a popularity contest, but is it a personality hire ? “In retrospect, Rudd’s win seems less about him and more about the economy, the state of the world and the electorate’s fatigue with John Howard’s prime ministership. But nearly 20 years on, it’s that line between politician and actual person that I remember best.“ 1 of 2
